A. Chevron Corporate Policy on Protecting People and the Environment



The Refinery is owned and operated by CUSA. CUSA is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it operates.  That commitment is documented in the vision and values outlined in CUSA Corporate Policy, "The Chevron Way - Getting Results the Right Way." CUSA's vision is "to be the global energy company most admired for its people, partnership and performance." The Chevron Way value of "Protecting People and the Environment" places the highest priority on the health and safety of the workforce (employees and contractors) and protection of the environment and assets.  CUSA policies, procedures and guidelines can be accessed by all employees on the company intranet.



To achieve and sustain its Vision CUSA has developed Tenets of Operation, a tool used by the workforce to guide daily decisions.  Leaders play an important role in setting expectations and reinforcing behaviors consistent with the tenets.  The Tenets of Operation are based on two key principles



Do it safely or not at all; and

There's always time to do it right.



B. Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Refinery is located in the City of Richmond, Contra Costa County, State of California. The Refinery is the largest refinery in the Bay Area with a capacity of 245,000 barrels of crude oil per day. The Refinery covers approximately 2,900 acres. There are approximately 1,300 CUSA employees at the Refinery, routinely augmented by contractors. Contractors are not used to operate or monitor process equipment.

 

The Refinery is located on a peninsula bordered by the San Francisco Bay to the north and west, the San Pablo Bay to the northeast, an acid regeneration facility to the east and the City of Richmond to the east and south. Point Molate and the Quarry Products Company are situated nearby on the western edge of the peninsula, the Parr-Richmond Terminal Corporation is loca

ted on the northwestern tip, and the Point San Pablo Yacht Harbor occupies a small section of the northern edge of the peninsula. The area immediately surrounding the refinery is nearly all industrial except for the neighborhoods of Point Richmond to the south, Atchison Village to the southeast, North Richmond to the northeast, and the Iron Triangle to the east.



The Refinery's primary business is to make transportation fuels from crude oil. The transportation fuel products produced at the Refinery include gasoline, jet fuel, and diesel fuel. The Refinery also produces lubricating oils and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). Several byproducts are produced by the Refinery's production processes, including sulfur and anhydrous ammonia, which are recovered from sulfur and nitrogen contained in the crude oil. The substances present at the refinery that are regulated by the federal RMP include flammable hydrocarbons and ammonia (NH3).



C. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program & Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



1. Management System 

The Refinery's senior managers have the overall responsibility for adherence to all federal, state, county and city regulations/ordinances. RMP and PSM are similar in their requirements. The Refinery's management system provides a framework to ensure Refinery personnel can integrate all of the regulatory requirements into Refinery work processes. 



Leadership 

The single largest factor for success is leadership. The Refinery's leaders are focused not only on getting results, but getting results the right way with behaviors in accordance with Chevron's values. They are accountable for stewarding the Refinery's RMP processes, and for both enabling and delivering performance. 



By their actions, the Refinery's leaders: 

- Cascade, manage and drive execution; 

- Reinforce the process safety culture; 

- Instill operational discipline - "every task the right way, every time;" and

- Ensure that they and the entire Refinery

workforce comply with prevention program requirements. 



Through personal example, the Refinery's leaders demonstrate that zero - whether related to process safety, personal safety, health, environmental, reliability, or efficiency incidents - is attainable.



Expectations & Policies

Expectations include compliance with all government laws and regulations. Refinery Instructions (RIs) are the primary method of setting and communicating expectations for the prevention program elements at the Refinery. These instructions are available on the Refinery Information Server, which is the Refinery's internal web page with pertinent information accessible to all personnel. Each RI is owned and maintained by an appropriate organization within the Refinery. The manager of each organization dedicates subject matter experts (SMEs) to periodically review and update the RIs. As part of the RI update process, all employees are given an opportunity to share input on potential changes. PSM-related RI's also include consultation with the United Steel Workers Union. After all feedback is received, changes are made. The RI is reviewed and approved by the owning manager, then  forwarded to senior managers for approval before taking effect. Refinery employees responsible for RI modifications must communicate those changes to all affected employees.



Vision 

The Refinery's management system begins with defining a vision of success and setting objectives. The vison and objectives drive the Refinery's Business Plan. The Refinery's Vision is to achieve and sustain world-class performance. There is no measure of the Refinery's performance with a higher priority than operating safely, reliably, and with concern for the health and well-being of the workforce, surrounding communities and the environment.



The Refinery's Vision is to systematically: 

- Achieve an incident- and injury-free workplace;

- Promote a healthy workforce and mitigate significant workplace health risks;

- Identif

ting minutes.



Resources

Necessary expertise to support the Refinery's work processes is provided through dedicated organizations such as Technical, Maintenance and Reliability, Health Environment and Safety and Process Safety. These groups possess a combination of technical training and practical hands-on experience which is necessary to not only solve problems and implement solutions, but to effectively communicate and enforce the need to implement the various prevention program elements. When a special situation requires outside expertise, necessary resources are assembled from other CUSA refineries, operating companies, or contract specialists.

 

2. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

The prevention programs described in the following section represent integrated, administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. All covered processes have control systems designed to maintain operating parameters (temperature, pressure, flow, level) within allowable limits. The covered processes are also equipped with alarms to alert personnel when the operating parameters exceed allowable limits. The Refinery uses procedures and trains personnel to ensure the correct response to the alarms. 



The Refinery has the following chemical-specific engineering controls to mitigate accidental releases:



Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The LPG storage area has been designed to minimize the risk of releasing flammable hydrocarbons to the atmosphere by providing high equipment reliability, minimizing the number of connections, avoiding unnecessary equipment, and protecting against inadvertent damage or failure. Some of the specific prevention and mitigation safeguards are described below.

- The LPG storage spheres are located away from the refinery perimeter to minimize the effect on the public in the event of a release;

- Spheres are separated by a distance equal to at least the diameter of the larger sphere;

- Each sphere is equipped

inery employees to prevent future occurrences. The Refinery regularly reviews metrics to prevent corrective actions from becoming overdue and also tracks the status of investigations so they are completed in a timely fashion. Corrective actions are either completed within one and one half (1.5) years after the completion of the investigation or added to the next planned turnaround. Copies of major incident investigation reports are retained for the life of the process unit.



Investigation results are reviewed with employees (including contract employees) whose job tasks are relevant to the findings in regular safety meetings, in other acceptable forums, or through incident bulletins. The management team discusses incidents that resulted in significant consequences as part of the daily safety discussions. 



Initial reporting of any incident to CCHMP is done in accordance with the CCHMP "Hazardous Materials Incident Notification Policy." This includes 72-hour and 30-day follow-up reporting and establishes minimum requirements for final reporting. 



Major incident reports are submitted CCHMP within 90 calendar days of the incident, unless the Refinery can demonstrate that additional time is needed due to the complexity of the investigation. In such cases a status report is prepared within 90 calendar days of the incident and every 30 calendar days thereafter until the investigation is complete. The final report is submitted within five (5) months of the incident.



The final incident report includes at a minimum the following: date and time of incident; date and time investigation began; a description of the incident; the factors that caused or contributed to the incident (root cause analysis); a list of any DMRs, PHAs, SPAs and HCAs reviewed; interim measures implemented; and recommendations for permanent corrective actions.

- Safe upper and lower operating limits and an evaluation of the consequences of deviations from those limits.

    

Information pertaining to the equipment in the process:

b. Process Hazards Analysis 

The Refinery's PHA program satisfies the requirements of Section 2762.2 of the CalARP regulation.



Per RI-363, "Process Hazards Analysis and Layers of Protection Analysis," a PHA is conducted on each process unit at the Refinery to systematically assess and reduce risks associated with loss of containment of highly hazardous materials. Initial PHAs have been completed on all existing process units and are performed for new processes or major modifications to existing processes. 



PHAs are performed with the following objectives:

- Identify the hazards of the substances and of the process;

- Identify external events (including seismic events) that could lead to a release;

- Identify possible equipment failures or human errors that could lead to a release;

- Identify releases that could possibly result in offsite consequences; 

- Evaluate the potential consequences and likelihood of an accidental release;

- Evaluate the safeguards used to prevent or mitigate an accidental release; and

- Propose recommendations that would reduce the risks, including changes to equipment design, facility or equipment siting, operating procedures, process technology, etc.



Each PHA

is conducted by a multi-disciplinary team. The PHA team is composed of a trained facilitator, an engineering representative, operations representative, and other specialists when needed (e.g., plant protection personnel, mechanics, inspectors, equipment reliability specialists, environmental specialists, etc.).



The PHA team considers the possible causes and potential consequences of deviations to identify hazardous conditions, analyzes existing safeguards, and makes recommendations for changes where appropriate. The PHA team uses the Chevron Integrated Risk Prioritization Matrix, to assess the severity, likelihood and relative risk of each cause-consequence scenario. PHA documentation is retained for the life of the process plus 30 years.



The HAZOP and What-if/Checklist methodologies are used to conduct PHAs at the Richmond Refinery and are selected based on the complexity of the process. Checklists are used to address Human Factors and Facility Siting issues.



Procedural PHAs may be used to evaluate risks associated with various activities. The following are qualifying procedures to be considered for Procedural PHAs: loading/unloading procedures; emergency procedures; start-up/shutdown procedures; procedures that have been identified as independent protection layers; and procedures that have been associated with root causes for MCAR incident investigations.



Recommendation resolutions are tracked and managed in an electronic database. The  database is the permanent record for each recommendation and includes the original team findings, the work plan to resolve the potential hazard, the target date for recommendation resolution and documentation of the work performed to resolve each recommendation. The database also records the person and department responsible for completing the recommendation. 



PHA recommendations not requiring a process unit shutdown are required to be completed within one year unless an alternative schedule is approved by CCCHSHMP

ief Devices (PRDs), gas detectors / deluge systems with automatic action and Process Control System (PCS) loop functions, among others. Approved and validated IPLs must be maintained and tested to verify their effectiveness in reducing the likelihood or consequence of a hazard scenario by an order of magnitude; and must be independent of the initiating event and other IPLs. 



d. Operating Procedures 

Clearly written safe work practices and operating procedures, especially for high-risk critical tasks, are important for the safe operation of the facility and to reduce the likelihood of a release of hazardous chemicals or energy that could impact employees, the community or the environment. RI-102, "Procedures for Instructions, Standards, and Manuals," RI-124, "Requirements for Operations Work Instructions" and The Electronic Operating Manual (EOM) Guidebook ensure that operating procedures and safe work practices are consistent and accurate.  These practices and procedures were developed in accordance with Section 2762.3 of the CalARP regulation.



Safe Work Practices include, but are not limited to:

- Hot Work and General Work Permits (RI-341)

- Control of Entry into Process Areas (RI-375)

- Control of Hazardous Energy (RI-9900) (includes lockout/tagout and lines/equipment opening)

- General Procedures for Entering/Working in Confined Spaces (RI-9920)



Electronic copies of operating procedures are available to all employees. Paper copies of emergency operating procedures are available in the control room of each process unit.

The Refinery's operating manuals include the following sections and appendices:

- Process description; 

- Normal operations, including startup and shutdown; 

- Emergency procedures, including shutdown; 

- Routine duties;

- A Consequences of Deviation (COD) table which identifies safe operating limits and the consequences of operating outside those limits. The COD tables explain the steps to correct or avoid the consequences of d

eviating outside the identified operating limits, including initiation of emergency shutdown;

- A health and safety section which provides a brief description of the chemicals and the associated hazards (including special or unique hazards) and engineering and administrative safeguards (i.e., ventilation, personal protective equipment (PPE) used to prevent exposures, etc.); and

- A description of all safety systems (i.e., alarms, interlocks, shutdowns), their functions, and their setpoints



Experienced plant operators are trained on the manual writing process and are utilized to create and maintain these documents.



The Refinery's Electronic Manual Management System (EMMS) ensures that Operations procedures and manuals are both current and accurate. The EMMS database provides employees a method to review and update documents according to a regular schedule. Operations procedures and manuals are reviewed at least every three years.



The Refinery's MOC process is required for changes to procedures, work instructions, and manuals other than minor clarifications related to formatting, grammar, and typos. Any revised documents are routed through the RBU for review and approval.



In addition, at the end of each calendar year, each RBU Manager is required to certify that the operating procedures for their area are current and accurate as part of the Richmond Refinery's annual compliance certification process.



The Richmond Refinery has a Leak Response Protocol that may be used to respond to over-pressurizing or overheating of equipment or piping and/or to handle leaks and spills, releases and discharges. Qualified employees shall, at a minimum, do one of the following:

(1) Shutdown and depressurize all process operations where a leak, release or discharge is occurring; or 

(2) Isolate any vessel, piping, and equipment where a leak, spill or discharge is occurring; or 

(3) Follow established criteria for handling leaks, spills, or discharges that are designed

to provide a level of protection that is functionally equivalent to, or safer than, shutting down or isolating the process.



e. Training 

The Refinery training program ensures employees have necessary skills and knowledge in order to perform their jobs in an incident-free manner, and in compliance with all applicable laws, regulations, and policies.

One of the purposes of the Refinery's written training plan is to provide affected personnel with an understanding of the types and causes of potential incidents or deviations within the process and the hazards associated with the process.



The operator training plan is outlined in the "Operations Training Process Manual." Maintenance  training is described in RI-368, "Mechanical Integrity," and contractor training is addressed in RI-366, "Contractors." The training program was developed in accordance with Section 2762.4 of the CalARP regulation and is comprised of the following:

- Fundamentals training;

- Plant or equipment specific formal training;

- Training provided as a result of an MOC, which includes training on updated or new procedures;

- Refresher training; and

- Training documentation



All operators receive training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment. The operators receive training specific to the operations of each process once they are assigned to a process unit. The training criteria are documented in job dimension documents that list the knowledge required (e.g., safe operating limits, safety system setpoints) and skills to demonstrate (e.g., emergency shutdown, lockout/tagout procedures). Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training. Documentation of the training is forwarded to the Learning & Development Department for filing and tracking.



Refresher training on specific operating procedures (e.g., normal operations, startup, shutdown), critical, seldom-done tasks, emerg

ency procedures, MOC reviews, safe work practices, (i.e., in plant hot work, lockout/tagout), and company-wide practices is provided.

- Computer based training on job specific PSM requirements 

- Simulator or oral discussion / demonstration when applicable

- Monthly "hypotheticals" or table top drills

- Computer based training on safe work practices

- Just in time training on startup, shutdown and related procedures before turnarounds

- Process safety topics delivered by Supervisors



The Refinery's current training schedule was developed with employee consultation and allows refresher training to be conducted at a minimum of every three years. Training documentation is tracked in the training database, crew turnover logs and safety database (hypotheticals).



In accordance with Section 2762.6 of the CalARP regulation, training may also be required as a result of the MOC process. The type of training is determined according to the complexity of the change (e.g., email notification, hands on/simulator training, classroom training). Training records are forwarded to and maintained by the Learning & Development (L&D) Department. The RBU is responsible for ensuring that the necessary training is conducted prior to implementation of a change.



A PSM General Awareness training class was developed in conjunction with USW Health and Safety representatives to ensure all affected employees are aware of and understand all Program 4 prevention program elements. Employees and employee representatives participating in a specialized team receive just in time training in the Program element(s) relevant to that team.



f. Mechanical Integrity

The Refinery has developed a mechanical integrity program in accordance with Section 2762.5 of the CalARP regulation. Proper design and maintenance of equipment and safety systems is essential to prevent releases of highly hazardous materials.



The mechanical integrity program applies to fixed and rotating equipment, instrumentati

on, and electrical systems. This includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems (including piping components such as valves), compressors, pumps, pressure relief devices, and vent systems, all of which are inspected following industry guidelines. The mechanical integrity program also applies to emergency shutdown systems and process controls, including monitoring devices, sensors, alarms, and interlocks.



RI-368, "Mechanical Integrity", describes the Refinery's policy and standards for the mechanical integrity program, which consists of the following:

? Quality assurance procedures - Members of the Technical, Maintenance and Reliability, and Procurement organizations develop and maintain purchasing documents for new and modified equipment. They review all new equipment against the purchasing documents to ensure that the equipment is fabricated in accordance with the specifications. They also conduct appropriate checks and inspections to ensure that the equipment is installed properly and is consistent with the design specifications and the manufacturer's instructions. In addition, all personnel and work involved with welding follows API, ASME, AWS and/or NBIC approved written QA/QC procedures. 



The preceding elements of the quality assurance program are often performed in conjunction with the MOC and PSSR programs. The Purchasing and Materials Management Department, in conjunction with Technical, Maintenance and Reliability personnel, develops and maintains purchasing documents for spare parts. This ensures that all maintenance materials and spare parts are suitable for the process.



? Written maintenance procedures for process equipment - Written procedures and checklists (including step-by-step instructions) are developed for maintaining process equipment. Copies of the procedures and checklists used are available through the Refinery Information Server from the Learning & Development EOM home page. Changes or additions to procedures identified d

uring maintenance activities are communicated to the Learning & Development Department and the procedures are updated by the respective owner utilizing the MOC process. Regularly scheduled maintenance (preventative maintenance) requests are automatically generated by a computer-based maintenance work management system. Non-preventive maintenance activities are also performed through the work management system (i.e., operators and engineers submit work requests to be scheduled by the Maintenance Planner/Scheduler). The Maintenance employees complete the work order documentation and the maintenance history records are updated in the work management system.

 

The Refinery's EMMS ensures that maintenance procedures and manuals are both current and accurate. The EMMS database provides employees a method to review and update documents according to a regular schedule. Maintenance procedures are reviewed every three years.



? Maintenance employee training - Maintenance skills training is provided to new hires over a 3-year period and includes assessments. Additional skills training is provided on an as-needed basis or when required by applicable codes and standards. The Learning & Development Department maintains documentation of skills training (e.g., union training program, community college training, specialty equipment training) and compliance training for maintenance employees. During initial employee training and refresher training, maintenance employees are provided with an overview of the process, the hazards associated with the process, and safe work practices. The Learning & Development Department maintains initial and refresher training records including content of training, instructor, and means used to verify competency. All welding related work and records are carefully monitored and controlled through the Refinery Inspection Department in accordance with ASME, AWS and NBIC requirements.



? Inspection, Testing and Preventative Maintenance (ITPM) for crit

ical equipment - Inspection, testing and preventative maintenance tasks and frequency of tasks for each piece of critical equipment were developed and documented by the Maintenance and Reliability organization. These ITPMs and their frequency are based upon jurisdictional requirements, manufacturer's recommendations, recognized and general accepted good engineering practices, operating history, and failure prediction and prevention analysis. Completed inspection and test documents include the inspector's name, date of the inspection or test, identification of the equipment, inspection and test procedures.  The results of the inspection or test are retained by the Maintenance and Reliability organization. Equipment inspectors or reliability analysts review the results of each inspection or test to ascertain whether the equipment is within the acceptable limits and to determine if the frequency of the inspections should be adjusted. Equipment outside of the acceptable limits is removed, repaired or replaced unless temporary protective measures can be put in place until the deficiencies are corrected. Inspection and test results are maintained for the life of the equipment. Some examples of inspections and tests include internal and external inspections, thickness monitoring, ultrasonic/radiography inspection, hydrotesting and infra-red scans. Instrumentation and control systems are also tested to ensure they will function as intended.



g. Management of Change (MOC) 

A change made in one part of the process may have unintended effects on other parts of the process because the Refinery is an integrated system. These changes are therefore appropriately scrutinized to avoid adverse effects to workers, the public,  and to the environment. 



The Refinery has a written MOC procedure, documented in RI-370, "Management of Change," which was developed in accordance with Section 2762.6 of the CalARP regulation. The MOC procedure ensures that all changes to the following are

are updated as necessary in accordance with the change being made, and reviewed by a subject matter expert; the MOC cannot be closed until the procedure update is verified as posted to the Refinery EOM



Most changes are relatively simple and require only communication of the change taking place. Each person affected by that change is sent a notification of change before the change is put into service. For more complex changes, a training package is developed and delivered to the affected employees, either on shift by the ABU Trainer, or in a classroom setting facilitated by the SME/Vendor.



The person that authorizes the startup of a change is typically an Operating Assistant. That person is responsible for determining that the assigned individuals have completed all required Evaluations and Actions identified on the MOC form before the change is put into service.



The MOC cannot be closed and will remain open until any procedure update is verified as posted to the Refinery EOM and any Process Safety Information is verified as updated on the web.

MOC records and documentation of completion of the tasks and reviews are maintained for the life of the process plus 30 years.



The Refinery also has a written instruction, RI-382 "Management of Organizational Change", that establishes the Policy for managing organizational changes. The purpose of the Management of Organizational Change (MOOC) Policy is to ensure the proper management of organizational changes exceeding 90 calendar days with the intent to prevent negative impact on worker safety and health, the community, and the environment.

Positions affected by this Policy include:

- Operations, including supervisors and engineers with direct responsibilities associated with processing units;

- Emergency response;

- Maintenance;

- Health and safety; and

- Contractors in permanent positions.



The MOOC Policy shall be used to analyze (a) a decrease in the number of positions or number of personnel, (b) a 1

5 % increase in the duties of a position, (c) reorganization of a department or substantive changes in the responsibilities of positions, and (d) a change to the shift duration or job classification of a position.



h. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) 

RI-367, "Pre-Startup Safety Review," was developed in accordance with Section 2762.7 of the CalARP regulation. PSSRs provide a system of checks and verifications, independent of the MOC process, to ensure that equipment is suitable for service and meets required specifications prior to startup in order to prevent the release of highly hazardous materials. In addition, PSSRs require that necessary operating, maintenance and emergency procedures have been written and that employees have been trained to safely operate the equipment.



The PSSR process takes place prior to startup of a new unit or the startup of an existing unit after a shutdown/turnaround event where the equipment is opened, or when a system/unit is idled for 6 months or longer. Changes requiring an MOC may also trigger a PSSR. This does not apply to MOCs initiated only for changes to Process Safety Information or Procedures as such changes do not require the startup/shutdown of a process unit or equipment.



There are three PSSR processes used in the Refinery, referred to as PSSR Appendices. 

- PSSR Appendix I is used to document the Pre-Startup Safety Review for normal maintenance shutdowns as well as assisting in the QA/QC process.

- PSSR Appendix II is used to document the Pre-Startup Safety Review for new or modified facilities.

- PSSR Appendix III is used to document the Pre-Startup Safety Review for MOC.



PSSR Appendix I or III can be used to document the Pre-Startup Safety Review for a partial/unplanned shutdown of a system. 



The PSSR facilitator convenes a team with knowledge of the process and expertise in their field. Team members can include representatives from the business unit, maintenance, engineering, and others depending on

the nature of the change. Team members are responsible for verifying that the following actions have been taken prior to the introduction of highly hazardous materials:

- Construction, maintenance, and repair work has been performed in accordance with design specifications;

- Process equipment has been maintained and is operable in accordance with design specifications

- Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;

- For new facilities, a PHA, HCA and DMR has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup;

- For modified facilities, the requirements of Management of Change (RI-370) have been met.

- Communication and/or training of affected operating, maintenance, technical, and contract workers have been completed and Process Safety Information is in place.



All required approvals must be obtained and any PSSR Items documented prior to startup. PSSR Items are incomplete tasks or discrepancies that will need to be resolved. . The PSSR facilitator and the appropriate Refinery Business Manager (or delegate) must review and agree on PSSR Items prior to startup of the system/unit or equipment. PSSR Items will be tracked to completion. Each PSSR Item will be specific, assigned to an individual, have a due date and be identified as required or not required prior to startup.

 

Authorization for startup requires completion of RI-367 Appendix I, II or III as appropriate. 



PSSR records are maintained for a minimum of 5 years.



i. Compliance Audits 

The Refinery has developed a compliance audit program RI-373, "Compliance Audit," in accordance with Section 2762.8 of the CalARP regulation. 



Knowledgeable Chevron personnel perform internal compliance audits at least every three years. Audits help certify compliance with regulations and ensure that process safety systems function in a manner to protect the community, the environment and employees from accidental releases of highly ha

zardous chemicals.



The audit team utilizes audit protocols to consistently perform the following:

- An assessment of the written prevention program elements;

- A review of records (i.e., completed hot work permits, MOC documents, incident investigations, equipment records) to assess implementation of the written prevention program elements;

- Interviews with employees and their representatives to assess their understanding of applicable programs (for example, whether personnel have a basic understanding of the mechanical integrity program); and

- Interviews with key personnel (those with primary responsibility for each element within the prevention program)

- Consultations with operators that have expertise and experience in each process audited



The audit team prepares a written report documenting audit team qualifications, scope, methods used, questions asked to assess each program element, findings and recommendations. The written report is available for employees and employee representatives in accordance with Section 2762.10. Any written comments from employees regarding the report will get a response, in writing, within 60 calendar days. The Refinery retains the three most recent compliance audit reports. Corrective actions developed by prevention program element owners are either completed within one and one half (1.5) years after the compliance audit report is certified by the Refinery Manager or added to the next planned turnaround.



j. Incident Investigation 

The Refinery's incident investigation procedure, documented in RI-371, "Near Loss, Event Reporting and Incident Investigation," was developed in accordance with Section 2762.9 of the CalARP regulation. RI-371 establishes procedures for investigating each incident that results in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a major incident.



Incident investigations provide the Refinery with the means to identify root causes or systemic factors and implement solutions to prevent future inciden

ts.



Refinery Business Managers are responsible for ensuring that personnel in his/her area promptly report any abnormal event or near miss, including those with the potential for catastrophic release. All incidents are reported into the Refinery's Incident database. Personnel trained in the methodology to be used (5 Why, TOP, Learning Team, SAFE, Why Tree and TapRoot®) are assigned as investigation team leader and/or investigation team facilitator. All Refinery employees are trained in TOP awareness. The experience and number of the other team members are dependent upon the nature of the incident. Typically, the incident investigation teams are comprised of a team leader and other employees (including contract employees) knowledgeable in the operation, design, and maintenance of the process. Major incidents require the use of the TapRoot® methodology (root cause analysis), which incorporates human factors in the investigation process. During the incident investigation related DMRs are reviewed.



The incident investigation team leader is responsible for initiating the investigation as soon as possible, but no later than 48 hours from the time of the incident or near miss. The team lead selects team members for Level 1 & 2 investigations and coordinates and supervises investigation team activities. Team members, with team leader/facilitator guidance, collect and analyze facts, identify root causes, develop appropriate solutions in order to avoid a repeat occurrence, and prepare the initial investigation report. The Management Sponsor has overall accountability for the investigation and its documentation, confirms team leader and members, assigns team members for Level 3 investigations, ensures needed resources are available, and reviews and approves the final investigation report.



The investigation report is entered into the Refinery's computerized incident database. Recommendations have an HCA performed, and lessons learned are communicated to the ref

am allows all employees and contractors to anonymously report hazards and receive feedback within 30 calendar days. The Refinery promptly prioritizes and resolves issues that could result in death or serious physical harm.



The Refinery has 2 full time Health and Safety Representatives and 2 full time TOP investigation representatives. All are members of the USW union. They are invited to participate in the design, development, implementation and continual improvement of Accidental Release Prevention elements.



l. Hot Work Permits

Controlling ignition sources is vital to the Refinery's Risk Management Plan. The hot work element prevents inadvertent ignition of flammables or combustibles when performing jobs such as welding and ensures that any fires which may occur can be readily suppressed and extinguished. Management personnel must authorize any hot work (e.g., cutting, grinding, burning, welding, brazing) to be performed in a unit and ensure appropriate safety precautions are taken prior to initiation of the work. The Refinery's hot work permit program, which is documented in RI-341, "Hot Work," was developed in accordance with Section 2762.11 of the CalARP regulation. The hot work permit program requires that employees complete permit requirements certifying that the applicable portions of the fire prevention and protection requirements are implemented prior to beginning hot work operations.



The fire prevention procedure restricts hot work in certain areas. When grinding, burning, welding, or brazing work is needed in these areas, an ignition source permit must be initiated by the Maintenance supervisor and approved by the local Operations supervisor. The permit is terminated when continued use of the ignition source is hazardous, when conditions of its issuance change, or when the permitted hot work has been inactive for more than two hours (unless tests show that conditions are still non-hazardous).

Three copies of the ignition source permit are maint

rk if continued use of the source of ignition becomes hazardous.



m. Contractors

RI-366, "Contractors," was developed in accordance with Section 2762.12 of the CalARP regulation. The contractor program ensures that safety issues are addressed during contractor selection and that CUSA and the contract company share responsibility for the safety of all employees. The Refinery and all contract companies are jointly responsible for safety and must ensure that contractor's employees are trained in and understand the following:

- Work practices necessary to perform the job;

- Hazards associated with a process;

- Applicable sections of the emergency response procedure; and

- Applicable safe work practices



CUSA's contractor safety management program employs a system of controls which requires contractors to meet CUSA's standards and expectations for supporting safe facility operations to protect contractors, employees, the community and the environment. The Refinery requires that potential contract companies complete and return a pre-qualification questionnaire regarding their safety programs to Contracts Administration for review against established criteria. The questionnaire includes confirmation that the company has an established written safety program, job qualification employee requirements, a program for random drug and alcohol testing, initial and refresher training programs, a behavioral based safety process and a short service employee program. Metrics, such as Total Recordable Incident Rate, are also considered when selecting contract companies. Contracts Administration may also request that the contract owner submit additional documentation, such as safety training records/logs. The contractor office field audit process also includes verification of appropriate skills and certification required to perform the job. Contract companies found to be acceptable against the established criteria are then logged into the Contractor Health Environmental Safety

Management (CHESM) IT database. The CHESM IT tool maintains files of the completed questionnaires and any additional information requested.



Accepted contractor employees are required to receive Refinery Instruction training before being allowed to work on-site. Each contractor employee must complete a course in general Refinery safety conducted by DISA, HASC or OSCA which offers DISA/Nor-Cal/LA Refinery Safety Orientation (DSOP/NCRSO/LARSO). This class has been upgraded by the State of California, SB54 and an addendum AB55 to 3 classes with a total of 20 hours of training: Refinery Safety Orientation (8 hours), Craft Specific (8 hours) and Principles of Refining (4 hours). In addition, each contractor employee must complete a course in Incident and Injury Free Indoctrination (IIFI), emergency procedures and Refinery-wide work practices specific to the Chevron Richmond Refinery. Training is also given on process-specific hazards related to the area in which the contractor employee will be working. These classes are conducted by OSCA and HASC and consist of Safe Work Practices 1 & 2 (SWP1, SWP2). Contractors must sign in at the control room for the unit they are working in, review the emergency response plan for the area before entering the unit, and sign out when leaving.



The Maintenance & Health, Environmental & Safety Departments audit contractor companies periodically. The frequency of the audits is adjusted according to the type of work performed (e.g., welding inside of a vessel). The contract owner ensures that each contractor provides proper training and maintains documentation for each contract employee. The contract owner also monitors contractor performance (i.e., compliance with Refinery safe work practices, knowledge of types of work, and the hazards involved). Documentation of the audits and on-site evaluations is maintained for a minimum of five years within the CHESM database.



It is critical for contractors and Refinery personnel to be aware o

f any unique hazards that may be encountered prior to performing work; therefore, a Hazard Analysis and Pre-Job Briefing is performed through the Permit to Work (PTW) process. Additionally, evaluation and communication of hazards is accomplished via the "Lock-out / Tag-out", and/or the "Confined Space Entry" work processes.



n. Hierarchy of Hazard Control Analysis (HCA)

The expectation of the Richmond Refinery is to focus on what can be done to eliminate process safety hazards before considering how to control them. To that end Richmond uses five levels within the inherent safety hierarchy: 1st Order Inherent, 2nd Order Inherent, Passive Safeguards, Active Safeguards, and Procedural Safeguards. Any of these risk management strategies may contribute to the overall safety of a process.

RI-398, "Inherently Safer Systems," describes the policy to ensure compliance with the RISO and Section 2762.13 of the CalARP regulation.



Chevron implements HCA for the following:

- Qualifying PHA Recommendations

- New Facilities, New Processes, and New Process Units

- Major Changes

- Major Incident Recommendations



o. Process Safety Culture Assessment

The Refinery's Safety Culture Assessment program is documented in RI-333, "Process Safety Culture Assessments" in accordance with Section 2762.14 of the CalARP regulation. 

Process Safety Culture at the Refinery is a combination of group values and behaviors that reflect whether there is a collective commitment by leaders and individuals to emphasize process safety over competing goals, to ensure protection of people and the environment.



The purpose of the Safety Culture Assessment is to assist in identifying pervasive attitudes or beliefs regarding risk tolerance in the work place with the intent to improve safety culture and decrease the number and severity of incidents. Process Safety Culture Assessments offer a gauge to the effectiveness of our health and safety programs by providing a view of attitudes, perceptions,

competencies and patterns of behavior.   



The Refinery applies approved data gathering techniques including Written Surveys, Focus Groups, and Observations to assess Process Safety Culture. The data gathering technique is determined during the planning of the Safety Culture Assessment and documentation of the selection of the data gathering technique and target participation levels is maintained. The data gathering technique will be selected based on how effective it may be to assess the required components and meet the target participation levels. 



The Refinery maintains a schedule for performing safety culture assessments. Interim assessment timing is also maintained on the schedule. The revalidations occur every five years.  Interim assessment will be performed between the five-year assessment time frame. The schedule is provided as a reference document to RI-333. 



At the start of a Process Safety Culture Assessment, a team of refinery employees with different backgrounds, including a USW Health and Safety representative or steward is identified to develop, implement the Process Safety Culture Assessment and evaluate the results. A Refinery Subject Matter Expert leads the Process Safety Culture Assessment team to ensure that the Safety Culture Assessment is performed as expected and as described in the RI-333. Previous Safety Culture Assessment results may be reviewed by the team. The Refinery Instruction contains direction for how results will be evaluated.



Once issues have been identified sufficiently to act upon, updates and additions may be made to the design, execution, evaluation, and continuous improvement plan to affect changes to safety-related behaviors.



p. Human Factors Program

RI-381, "Human Factors Program," describes how the Refinery meets the requirements of Section 2762.15 of the CalARP regulation. This program looks at the interactions between workers, processes/equipment and management systems. The Refinery is committed to apply

ing a systematic approach to identify and resolve human factor issues to prevent accidental releases of highly hazardous materials. 



A human factors analysis is applied to the following prevention program elements: 

- Process Hazards Analysis; 

- Hierarchy of Hazards Control Analysis

- Major Change

- Operating and Maintenance Procedures; 

- Management of Organizational Changes; and

- Root Cause Analysis.



q. Stop Work Authority

The Refinery has a history of using Stop and Pause Work Authority for personal safety.  Employees feel they can stop unsafe work.  A Refinery Protocol was developed in accordance with Section 2762.16 of the CalARP regulation and is available on the Refinery Intranet.  The protocol defines when documentation is required and the tool that is used. The protocol gives all employees, including employees of contractors the authority to:

- Refuse to perform a task where doing so could reasonably result in death or serious physical harm;

- Recommend to the operator in charge of a unit that an operation or process be partially or completely shut-down, based on a process safety hazard; and, 



The protocol also gives the qualified operator in charge of a unit the authority to partially or completely shut-down an operation or process, based on a process safety hazard.



r. Accidental Release Prevention Program Management System

RI-360, "Richmond Refinery PSM Policy," was developed in accordance with Section 2762.16 of the CalARP regulation.  The management system program is reviewed every 3 years.  The RI includes the following:



- Job descriptions and roles for each prevention program element

- Organizational chart

- A written communication plan for safety, operations and maintenance information

- Policies and procedures for findings, recommendations and corrective actions 

- Process safety performance indicators reported to CCHMP



D. The Five-Year Accident History

Section 2750.9 of the Cal/ARP regulation requires facilities t

o compile a five-year history of accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



Communicating the five-year accident history to the public informs the community of the factors causing or contributing to accidental releases, the onsite and offsite impacts of accidental releases, and the procedural and technological changes implemented to minimize the possibility of recurrence. The intent of this information exchange is to create an informed community while also documenting that accidental releases are investigated and concrete changes are made to protect against recurrence.



There are no incidents in the last five years that meets the above criteria. 



E. The Emergency Response Program

The Refinery maintains an emergency response program designed to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. As part of the emergency response program:



- There is a written ERP for responding to accidental chemical releases, including releases of regulated substances. The ERP is reviewed to ensure that it remains accurate and current. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties; 

- There are procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment;

- The Refinery works closely with local emergency responders (primarily the Richmond Fire Department) in preparing for emergencies; and

- There are procedures for notifying the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.



The Refinery emergency response program is discussed in more detail in the following subsections.



Emergency Response Plan

The ERP addresses all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for perso

nnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release does occur, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. The ERP is documented in a series of RIs and is available to all employees. Hard copies of the ERP, and manuals of emergency plans and procedures, are also maintained throughout the Refinery. 



The ERP is reviewed annually by the Manager of the Refinery Fire Department and updated to ensure that it remains accurate and current. Every employee receives training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.



The ERP includes the chemical-specific emergency response procedures for releases of RMP-regulated chemicals. The chemical-specific emergency response plans identify the characteristics of the chemical, emergency response and first aid procedures, and the community notification system. These plans also identify concentrations of chemicals that would trigger specific types of emergency response and when to notify the public.



In addition, all employees are trained on the ERP upon initial assignment. The level of emergency response training corresponds to the emergency response duties of the employee. Refresher training is provided annually or as required by appropriate members of management or trainers for thoroughness and accuracy.



In addition to the ERP, the Refinery also has local EAPs, which are posted in all buildings and operating area control rooms. All employees or contractors entering a process area must review the EAP for that area prior to entry. The EAP summarizes the first actions that are to be taken in the event of an emergency (e.g., stay clear of area, call emergency number, move indoors, etc.) and the means for reporting fires and emergencies (a single three digit phone number). The EAP also has guidelines for sheltering-in-place, evacuations, and earthquakes, as well as maps with evacuation routes and meeting places.



Emerg

ency Operating Procedures, which are a part of the prevention program, are another critical component of emergency preparedness. These procedures outline the steps to be taken to control or shut down a process unit in the event of an emergency situation (e.g., fire, earthquake, release, etc.). Operators for the process are trained in these procedures.



The Refinery also has various mitigation safeguards in place to minimize impact of chemical or toxic releases. Examples include H2S scrubbers, emergency deluge systems and administrative controls to manage ammonia and LPG inventory.



Refinery Fire Department

The Refinery Fire Department responsibilities include inspections of fire-related equipment, permit authorization for hot work and confined space entry, security, and a variety of other tasks related to fire prevention and emergency response. Other members of the Refinery Fire Department are volunteers consisting of employees from the Operations, Maintenance, and Technical Divisions. Each volunteer member receives approximately 100 hours of training each year. 



Unlike other refiners in the area who have separate teams to deal with different types of emergencies, the Refinery Fire Department trains its personnel to handle any emergency that might occur. These emergencies involve all aspects of firefighting, including fires in process plants, building fires, storage tank fires, wild land fires, or fires related to transportation modes, including ships, barges, tank cars, and rail cars. Refinery Fire Department personnel are trained in confined space, high angle, and heavy rescue procedures. In addition, all of the full-time members are certified Hazardous Material Technicians, and are qualified to deal with any hazardous material incident including any oil spills at the ship and barge loading facilities. The Refinery Fire Department also responds to medical emergencies; many members are California State Certified Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs). 



A v

ariety of emergency response equipment exists at the Refinery and includes 25 emergency response vehicles (including fire trucks), 2500 fire extinguishers, water deluge systems, in-plant stationary fire monitors, fixed foam systems, and a water fog system. All of this equipment is maintained, inspected, and tested as outlined in the Refinery Fire Department Procedures and Policies.



Coordination

The Refinery conducts emergency drills in which an offsite responding agency (Richmond Fire Department and/or CCHMP), the Refinery Fire Department, and non-responding employees work together to resolve the given scenario. This pre-planning activity ensures that the members of the responding agencies are familiar with the Refinery, the hazards of the regulated substances, the resources available at the Refinery, and the locations of these resources. It also clearly identifies the capabilities and limitations of each responding agency. These drills are conducted at least once a year.



The Refinery also works closely with the CCHMP for any necessary response to hazardous material releases (such as downwind air monitoring) and to alert the public in case of accidental releases, fires, or explosions in accordance with CCHMP's Emergency Response Area Plan. The Refinery worked with CCHMP to establish the CWS and the TENS zones, which provide incident notification to the community.



The Refinery Fire Department also provides mutual aid to the City of Richmond Fire Department and responds outside of the refinery within the City of Richmond whenever asked to do so by the city fire department. The Refinery Fire Department also belongs to an industrial mutual aid organization, Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization (PMAO), and has responded to other oil companies and chemical plants during emergencies. Likewise, the emergency response resources of the other companies in PMAO are available for an emergency at the Refinery, if needed.



Notification

The Emergency Response Program

has plans and procedures in place for notifying employees, on-site and off-site emergency responders, government agencies, the community, and local hospitals in the event of a release. These procedures are given in RI- 434, "Reporting Hazardous Spills and Releases", and are available on the Refinery Information Server.



Upon the first detection of a release or other emergency situation, an employee would call the central emergency phone number, which initiates the emergency response. Alarms or sirens are used to notify personnel of an emergency situation, and appropriate actions (e.g., shelter-in-place) would be taken according to the EAP.



The Refinery has an internal Refinery-wide alarm system consisting of multiple sirens and loudspeakers to alert personnel to any incidents that may have impact on more than one area of the facility. In addition, there is a dedicated emergency intercom system to provide follow-up information during a widespread Refinery incident. Each operating area of the Refinery has a local alarm system for incidents within their operating units. Operators routinely carry in-plant two-way radios that are used for both normal and emergency communications.



Employees who do not respond to an emergency and contractors are trained in the Refinery EAP. Persons who are inside, or near, a building are instructed to shelter-in-place inside the building. Any individual who is not in, or near, a building are instructed to proceed via a safe route to a designated assembly site. There are designated assembly sites for both local area emergencies and for a Refinery-wide emergency. The senior Refinery employee at any building or assembly site is responsible for collecting names of the persons present and communicating them to the Refinery Fire Department Dispatcher.



For hazardous material spills or releases with potential offsite impacts (or meeting other reporting criteria), CCHMP, the Richmond Fire Department, and other agencies are notified immed

iately. If appropriate, the CCHMP will activate the CWS to alert the community. The CWS consists of several components as follows.



- Sirens. Initially, four sirens may be activated by Chevron to provide a loud audible signal throughout the cities of Richmond and San Pablo. A total of 20 sirens are available and can be activated by CCHMP. Upon hearing the sirens, residents should proceed indoors to shelter-in-place and turn on their TV or radio to obtain further instructions or more information about the incident



- Telephone Emergency Notification System. The TENS system calls households and businesses and transmits short messages about the incident and recommended protective actions



- Media. An initial warning, updates, instructions, and an "all-clear" would be distributed to the community through radio, television, and cable by CCHMP when there is no longer a potential danger to the community





F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chevron Richmond Refinery is dedicated to implementing projects to provide significant reduction for the potential of catastrophic releases at the facility. A sampling of our projects that will have significant impact on the facilities process safety management are listed below.



The Refinery continues to upgrade with planned changes due to recommendations from ongoing facility PHAs, internal and external audits, incident investigation findings, employee suggestions, latent conditions findings, seismic assessments, and mechanical integrity testing and inspections. 



- The Richmond Refinery is developing Fixed Equipment Asset Strategies to optimize mechanical availability and to prevent/mitigate loss of containment in fixed equipment. An asset strategy is the documented plan for operating, monitoring and maintaining the fixed equipment. An asset strategy identifies applicable damage mechanisms and determines the need for operating limits known as integrity operating windows.



- There is an initiative within Chevron to de

liver a consistent and standardized approach to Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) design. This centralized program will identify opportunities, develop strategies and deploy automated process safety system solutions that are aligned with industry standards.

 

- The Refinery has installed vibration protection shut down systems on centrifugal pumps used in high consequence services to reduce the risk of significant loss of containment due to bearing failures.  Based on the outcome of upcoming HAZOP/LOPA evaluations, the Refinery will also be considering mechanical seal upgrades to these same high consequence pumps.  



- The Refinery continues to conduct Procedural PHAs in order to identify and mitigate potential error traps associated with operating work instructions. The current focus is on emergency, startup and shutdown procedures.
